title: 111_hr5698
content: PROTECTION OF EMPLOYEES FROM RETALIATION BY THEIR EMPLOYER FOR COOPERATING IN INVESTIGATIONS. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation against employees who report violations or refuse to participate in misconduct. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section protecting employees who report violations or refuse to participate in misconduct related to their job duties, testify in proceedings, or commence actions under the Act. Employees protected under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 can bring enforcement actions if they face discrimination for reporting violations, refusing to participate in misconduct, testifying in proceedings, or commencing actions under the Act. Employees protected under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 can take legal action under specific rules and procedures outlined in section 20109 of title 49, US Code. District court review can be sought within 90 days of receiving a final determination by the Secretary of Labor. Any reference to the Act includes amendments made by it. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation against employees who report violations or refuse to participate in misconduct. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to protect employees who report violations or refuse to participate in misconduct related to their job duties, testify in proceedings, or commence a proceeding under the Act. Employees covered by the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act are protected if they report violations, refuse to participate in misconduct, testify in proceedings, or commence a proceeding under the Act. They can bring an enforcement action if they allege discrimination by an employer. Employees covered by the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act can take legal action under specific rules and procedures if they face discrimination by an employer. They have 90 days to seek district court review after receiving a final determination by the Secretary of Labor.
